Kaimati
(Fried Dumplings),common snacks,"""Kaimatis get their unique flavour from the style with which yeast is applied on wheat flour. This traditional breakfast dish or day snack is common among the Swahili and Bajuni communities and was inherited from Arab culture. It serves the whole family.""",20,30,4,"2 cups (280 g) wheat flour, refined
column3: � tsp. (3 g) vanilla essence, clear
column5: 1� tbsp. (12 g) yeast, dry
column6: 5 1/8 cups (1000 g) cooking oil
column7: 4 tbsp. (56 g) sugar","Put yeast in a small container.
column8: Add 50ml of warmed water.
column9: Add 4 tbsp. of sugar and allow to stand for 3 minutes.
column10: Meanwhile, warm the rest of the water in a cooking pot.
column11: Mix dry ingredients together
column12: flour, cardamoms and vanilla essence in a bowl.
column13: Add � cup (50 g) of oil into the mixture and rub in until finely absorbed.
column14: Add the yeast preparation to the flour mixture, adding the lukewarm water gradually while mixing to a semi-solid consistency.
column15: Cover with a dry towel/ cloth and allow to stand for 4 minutes until the dough rises.
column16: In a pan put the rest of the oil and heat for 7 minutes or until the oil bubbles when a pinch of dough is dropped in the oil.
column17: Shape the dough into round balls and put into the hot oil, keep turning to cook evenly.
column21: � tsp. (4 g) vanilla essence, clear","<sugar syrup>: Mix the sugar, water and vanilla essence in a cooking pan.
column22: Put on the heat for 5 minutes.
column23: Stir to prevent sugar from sticking on the sides of the pan
column25: Add the fried dumplings to the sugar syrup and stir to coat them in the syrup while still on the heat.
column26: Swirl until the syrup covers all the dumplings.

column1:
Mahamri
(Swahili Doughnuts),common snacks,"""This is a typical traditional recipe among the Swahilis. A true delicacy enjoyed by the entire family, serves as a breakfast meal as well as a whole day snack. Mahamri has a unique taste influenced by the freshly squeezed coconut milk.""""""",60,5,4,"3 � cups (525 g) wheat flour, refined
column3: 9 tbsp. (123 g) white sugar
column5: 1 tsp. (2 g) cardamom
column6: � cups (182 g) water
column7: 8 1/8 cups (1735 g) cooking oil","Break the coconut shell, drain the water and grate the flesh.
column8: Squeeze the coconut milk from the grated coconut flesh using a cloth.
column9: Set aside the thick coconut milk.
column10: Add � cup of warm water to squeeze out any remaining milk.
column11: In a bowl, mix a pinch of sugar with the yeast and add the � cup of water used to squeeze the last batch of coconut milk. Stir and set aside for 5 minutes for the yeast to rise.
column12: In a separate bowl, mix the dry ingredients
column14: Add the yeast mixture to the dry ingredients.
column15: Add 4 tablespoons of oil and the thick coconut milk into the yeast and dry ingredients mixture.
column16: Knead the dough as you add the remaining water to a firm feel.
column17: Set the dough aside for 10 minutes for sugar to dissolve.

column1: Cover with a cloth.
column2: Knead the dough again to mix the sugar and to improve the

column1: Texture.
column2: Cover with a dry cloth and allow to stand for 30 minutes.
column3: Divide the dough into small-medium size balls. Set them

column1: aside and cover with a dry cloth for 15 minutes.
column2: When well raised, roll out each ball into flat discs and cut

column1: each into four triangle shaped portions.
column2: Heat the remaining  oil for 15 minutes to 173�C.
column3: Fry the mahamri and turn after 40 seconds. The mahamri will

column1: turn golden brown when ready.
column2: Remove the first batch of mahamri from oil and place onto

column1: paper towels to drain the oil.
column2: Continue frying the rest in batches until all are done.

column1:
Enriched Mandazi
(East African Doughnuts, Enriched),common snacks,"A popular snack among urban dwellers across the country, enriched mandazi is a doughnut made with
eggs plus fresh milk and conditioned with margarine
column2: it is a favourite breakfast item for the entire family.",45,30,4,"7 cups (1063 g) self-raising wheat flour
column3: 3 eggs (179 g)
column5: Rind from 2 lemons (15 g)
column6: � cup (144 g) sugar
column7: � tsp. (2 g) salt, iodized
column8: 7 cups (1039 g) cooking fat
column9: 11/3 cups (289 g) cow milk
column10: 1� cups (282 g) water","Put flour, salt, sugar and lemon rind into a bowl and

column1: Mix.
column2: Mix all the water with the milk and warm.
column3: Add margarine into the dry ingredients and rub in.
column4: Add eggs onto the dry ingredients and mix.
column5: Add the warm diluted milk into the bowl and knead the mixture into a soft dough.
column6: Cover the dough with a dump cloth for 40 minutes.
column7: Heat all the cooking fat in a pot for 10 minutes or until the oil bubbles when a pinch of dough is dropped in

column1: the oil.
column2: Roll out the dough into the desired thickness
column3: about a

column1: � of an inch thick.
column2: Cut the dough into preferred shapes.
column3: Gently drop the cut-out pieces into the hot oil.
column4: Fry one side until golden brown and turn.
column5: Remove from oil and place onto paper towels to drain

column1: any excess oil.
column2: Repeat the process with the rest of the pieces.

Maize Porridge
(Uji wa Mahindi),porridges,"Whole maize flour has been used for many years by many communities in Kenya to prepare porridge.
Enriched with milk, it also serves as an infant dish. ",5,25,4,"1 �� cups (236 g) whole maize flour,
white
column3: 1�� cups (330 g) cow milk","Put 5 cups of the water into the cooking pot, cover and

column1: heat until it boils.
column2: Meanwhile mix the maize flour with 2 cups cold water

column1: separately. Use cold water to avoid forming lumps.
column3: Add the mixture into boiling water while stirring and

column1: continue stirring to avoid forming lumps.
column3: Add milk and cook for a further 7 minutes.

Sorghum, Finger Millet and Maize Porridge",porridges,"This recipe is made from a mixture of 3 grains ground together into flour. It is rich in nutrients and is enriched with milk. Popular among many households in Kenya as a family dish, the porridge, serves infants/

column1: children.",5,30,4,"8 tbsp. (83 g) sorghum flour, whole
whole
white
column3: 7 �� cups (1833 g) water","Mix the whole maize flour, sorghum flour and finger millet into a bowl.
column4: Add 2 cups of cold water into the flour mixture, stir

column1: until smooth using a wooden cooking stick
column2: Bring 5 cups of water to boil in a cooking pot.
column3: After the water has boiled, add the mixture as you

column1: stir. Keep stirring to avoid forming lumps.
column2: Add milk after 10 minutes of cooking.
column3: Keep stirring until cooked. If the porridge is too thick

is achieved.

Cassava Porridge (Uji wa Muhogo),porridges,"The ancient cassava has been a traditional staple in most Kenyan communities, particularly Western and Coastal regions. Dried and ground into fine flour, cassava makes refreshing porridge for the entire family.",2,20,6,10 tbsp. (100 g) cassava flour
column3: 8 ½ cups (1840 g) water,"Boil 6 cups of water in a pot for 6 minutes.
column4: In a separate bowl, add 2 ½ cups of water to the cassava flour and mix to a medium paste.
column5: Add the paste to the boiling water and stir continuously until the mixture boils to prevent lumps.
column6: Continue boiling for 13 minutes and add sugar.
column7: Stir, remove and serve the porridge.",121,0.0,6.8,0.1,0.3,0,0.1,0.05,,

column1: Pilau (Spiced Rice),rice dishes,"Pilau is the king of traditional rice cuisine among the Swahili community. Culturally, it is a must cook dish
on Friday particularly during lunch. It is enjoyed by the entire family and often served with tomatoes, onions
and chillies salad commonly known as (��kachumbari�� or salsa) and accompanied with a ripe banana.
This tastefully spiced dish is characterized by whole potatoes and meat chunks as key ingredients.",20,60,4,"3 1/3 cups (595 g) raw white rice
column3: 10 seeds (1 g) cardamom, whole
column5: 5 seeds (1 g) black pepper, whole
column6: 5 seeds (1 g) cloves, whole
column7: 6 tsp. (30 g) salt, iodized
column8: 2 tbsp. (11 g) cumin
column9: 4 potatoes, unpeeled, raw (840 g)
column10: 3 onions, red skinned, unpeeled, raw (387 g)
column11: 5 cloves (17 g) garlic, whole
column16: 1 �� cups (293 g) cooking oil","Cut meat into medium size chunks.
column17: Boil the meat in a large cooking pot with all the

column1: water for 30 minutes, drain the water and set
both meat and water aside.
column2: Prepare and chop onions and potatoes, grate

column1: capsicum, pound coriander, crush garlic and
ginger.
column2: Place each prepared ingredient in small separate

column1: bowls.
column2: Place each prepared ingredient in small separate

column1: bowls.
column2: Toast cardamom, cinnamon, cloves and black

column1: pepper together until they produce an aroma.
Grind them.
column2: Put oil into the pan used to boil the meat.
column3: Add onions into the hot oil and cook for 5 minutes

column1: until they brown (a golden-brown colour).
column3: Add all browned spices

column1: cloves, cinnamon, cardamom after 3 minutes.
column2: Add capsicum, coriander and potatoes after 1

column1: minute and stir. Meanwhile, wash the rice.
column2: Add rice and salt after 3 minutes and stir in to

column1: properly mix the ingredients.
column2: Add water drained from boiling the meat, stir the

column1: rice and bring the mixture to boil for 25 minutes.
column2: Add the cooked meat to the boiling mixture.

column1: Mseto wa Maharagwe (Rice with Beans),rice dishes,"��Mseto wa Maharagwe�� is the Swahili name for rice that is made with beans in one pot. It is a common
recipe among many communities in Kenya. Mainly prepared as a main meal during lunch time, it is eaten
by the whole family. Sometimes, this dish is eaten for supper.",165,225,6,"3 cups (505 g) kidney beans, raw
column3: 4 cups (684 g) raw white rice, long grain
column4: 1 large onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled

column3: 1 �� cups (238 g) cooking oil
column4: 2 tbsp. (27 g) salt","Soak the beans in 13 �� cups of water for 2 hours

column1: 35 minutes.
column2: Boil the soaked beans for 3 hours.
column3: Peel, wash and cut onions and tomatoes separately.
column4: Fry the onions in cooking oil until golden-brown,

column1: add the tomatoes until they have cooked down to
a paste.
column3: Add the previously boiled beans and stir until

column1: evenly mixed and well coated with the tomatoes.
column2: Add 8 cups of water and let it boil.
column3: Wash rice until water runs clear.
column4: Add rice. When it starts boiling, reduce fire and let

column1: it cook on low heat for 20 minutes.
Mseto wa Ndengu (Rice with Green Grams),rice dishes,"This recipe is named in Swahili ��Mseto wa Ndengu�� meaning a mix of green grams and rice. It is uniquely
prepared using freshly squeezed coconut milk. Very popular in the Kenyan coastal region, it is served to
infants and adults alike as a main meal during lunch or dinner. In other communities, this recipe is prepared
without coconut milk.",15,90,6,"3 �� cups (621 g) raw white rice
column3: �� cup (180 g) coconut milk

column1: g)
column3: 13 cups (2832 g) water","Boil the green grams in 6 cups of water for 1 hour and

column1: set aside.
column2: Prepare and finely chop the onions.
column3: In a separate cooking pot, add 7 cups of water.
column4: Add chopped onion and salt to the water and bring to a

column1: boil for 10 minutes.
column2: Add the rice to the boiling mixture and cook until the

column1: water starts to dry up.
column2: Add the green grams and reduce heat. Cook for 8 minutes.
column3: Add the coconut milk and stir after 2 minutes.
column4: Leave covered over very low heat to dry for 10 minutes.
column5: Turn off the heat and serve hot.",433,1.3,18.4,3.7,1.5,1,0.8,0.48,,

column1: Mukimo (Fresh Maize, Potatoes & Pumpkin Leaves),mashed dishes,"This is a common dish among the Kikuyu, Meru and Embu communities. Often eaten for lunch or dinner, it
can be served with meat stew. This dish is served as a main meal to the whole family.",15,75,4,"6 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, raw (876g)
column3: 2 �� cups (479 g) green maize, white, boiled
column5: 2 �� tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized","Peel the potatoes and wash.
column6: Wash the pumpkin leaves and chop finely
column7: Put 2 cups of water into a pot. Add the potatoes,

column1: pumpkin leaves and salt.
column2: Cover the pot and boil the mixture for 20 minutes.
column3: Add the boiled maize and cover to cook for 10

column1: minutes.
column2: Remove from fire and mash to serve.",457,1.0,18.5,3.0,6.8,14,1.6,0.93,,

column1: Mukimo (Maize, Beans, Potatoes & Pumpkin Leaves),mashed dishes,"This recipe is a family dish common among the Kikuyu, Meru and Embu communities. It is served mainly
for lunch or dinner.",15,60,4,"10 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white (1386 g)
column3: 7 �� cups (1182 g) white maize and kidney

column1: beans, cooked
column3: 2 �� tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized","Peel, wash and cut the potatoes.
column5: Meanwhile, measure 7 �� cups of previously

column1: boiled maize and beans mixture (the ratio of
maize to beans is 1:2).
column2: Put all the water into the empty cooking vessel.

column1: Add potatoes and salt.
column2: Boil the potatoes for 20 minutes and add the

column1: cut pumpkin leaves. Cover the pot and cook
for 2 minutes.
column2: Add the cooked maize-bean mixture and cover

column1: to cook for 20 minutes.
column2: Remove from heat and mash the mixture.

column1: Mukimo wa Njahi (Black Beans, Green Bananas & Potatoes),mashed dishes,"This is a delicacy among the Kikuyu community particularly in Nyeri. Commonly referred to as ��Mukimo
wa Njahi��, this dish was traditionally prepared for lactating mothers and during occasions like dowry ceremonies.
In modern times it remains important as a family dish mainly served during lunch or dinner.",20,240,4,"6 (1.2 kg) potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, raw
column3: 2 �� cups (497 g) njahi, dolichos lablab,

column1: raw, dry
column3: 4 tsp. (20 g) salt, iodized","Boil 2 �� cups of njahi (dolichos lablab) in 21 cups of

column1: water for 3 hours.
column2: Peel and wash the potatoes and green bananas in separate

column1: bowls, chop them.
column2: Put the rest of the water into a separate cooking pot.
column3: Add the chopped potatoes, green bananas and salt.
column5: Add the cooked black beans, cover and cook for 20

column1: minutes.
Ashir,maize dishes,"This dish is typical to the Borana s. A delicious meal of huskless maize mixed with milk. The husks are
removed prior to cooking by pounding with a mortar and pestle. The mixture is boiled with added sugar
and salted for a tantalizing taste.",10,135,4,"8 � cups (1536 g) pounded maize, white, de-germed
column3: 6 � tbsp. (88 g) sugar
column5: 29 2/3 cups (6430 g) water","Sort and wash the pounded maize.
column6: Put all the water in the cooking pot and add the pounded maize.
column7: Put it on heat and boil.
column8: Boil for 2 hours, remove from heat and strain excess water.
column9: After draining water put back on the heat, add salt, sugar, milk and stir.

column1: Githeri (Fresh Beans and Maize),maize dishes,"Stewed fresh maize and beans is commonly known as Githeri. This is a variant of the Githeri dishes that
uses fresh maize and beans. It is popular among communities in agricultural areas such as Eastern, Central
and Western. This recipe is common during the season when maize and beans are green about a month
to harvesting. It is usually served as a main dish in most communities and as a breakfast dish among the
Luhya communities.",120,20,4,"4 green maize cobs with kernels, (2 kgs)
column3: 9 � cups (2005 g) water
column5: 1 � cups (187 g) cooking fat
column6: 5 � tsp. (28 g) salt, iodized","Remove fresh beans from pods. Put in a bowl or container.
column7: Remove maize cobs with kernels from the husks.
column8: Remove maize kernels from the cobs by hand.
column9: Mix and wash the maize and beans.
column10: Boil in 9 � cups of water for 2 hours until cooked.
column11: Prepare the onions and chop into a separate bowl.
column13: Heat cooking fat into a pan and add the spring onions.
column14: Cook the spring onions until they soften.
column15: Add the boiled maize-beans mixture. Cover with a pan.
column16: Add salt and continue cooking while stirring periodically
column17: Once ready, remove from fire and serve.",751,7.6,15.1,7.8,10.4,6,1.7,1.21,,

column1: Githeri (Stewed Maize & Beans),maize dishes,"This is yet another variant of githeri. It is mainly prepared using dry maize and beans. It is common among
most communities in Western, Central, Eastern and Rift Valley parts of Kenya. This variant of githeri is one
among the most common staples in Kenya. It is mostly eaten as a main dish during lunch time and dinner
by the entire family. It is well balanced in nutrients and is considered complete on its own.",10,15,4,"11 cups (1730 g) maize and beans, dry, boiled
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (132 g)
column3: 1/3 cup (69 g) cooking oil
column5: 13/4 cups (389 g) water","Measure 11 cups of previously boiled maize and beans mixture (the ratio of maize to beans is 1:2).
column6: Prepare, wash and chop the onion.
column7: Pour oil in a cooking pot over fire, add onions and cook for 2 minutes and add salt.
column8: Add the boiled maize-bean mixture.
column9: Stir and add 1 3/4 cups water.
column10: Cover and let the mixture to cook for 10 minutes.

column1: Mchuzi wa Maharagwe (Bean Stew),legume dishes,"The ancient bean stew is chief among the legume stews in Kenya. Different varieties of beans are used to
prepare bean stew by different communities depending on availability. Most communities in Kenya utilize
bean stew as an accompaniment to starchy dishes such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. It is commonly eaten for
lunch or dinner.",160,30,4,"2 2/3 cups (462 g) beans, kidney, dry
column3: 1 tomato, red, raw (140 g)
column5: � cup (40 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 � tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized
column7: 9 stalks (56 g) coriander
column8: ,Boil all the beans in 9 cups of water for 2 hours 30 minutes
column9: Prepare and cut the vegetables (coriander leaves, tomatoes and onions) into small pieces in separate bowls.
column10: In a pot, add � cup of oil and turn on the heat.
column11: Add the onions and cook for 7 minutes in a covered pan on low heat.
column12: After 10 minutes, add the tomatoes and cook while stirring to mix.
column13: Add the coriander leaves and mix then add the beans.
column14: Add 1 3/4 cups of water followed by 1 tbsp. salt and cover the pot for 5 minutes. Stir to mix.
column15: Cover the vessel and cook for 4 minutes.

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu Kamande (Lentil Stew),legume dishes,Lentil stew is made from lentil grains which give a characteristic taste to the dish. It is quite aromatic and provides the desired fragrance as an accompaniment to starch dishes such as rice and chapatti. It is usually served during lunch or dinner and is common in most parts of the country.,60,20,6,"2 1/3 cups (466 g) lentils, dry, raw
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (161 g)
column5: 1/3 cup (63 g) cooking oil
column6: 3 tsp. (15 g) salt, iodized",<preparation>: Sort and wash all the dry lentils. Put in a cooking pot and boil in 9 cups of water for 1 hour.
column7: Remove from heat and set aside.
column8: Wash and cut tomatoes and onions in separate bowls.,455,3.0,11.1,7.1,4.5,3,2.0,0.93,,<stewing>: Add cooking oil into the vessel and heat for 1 minute.
column9: Add onions and cook for 6 minutes.
column10: Add tomatoes and salt.
column11: Cook for 7 minutes while stirring to mix.
column12: Add the pre-boiled lentils and mix.
column14: Cover the vessel and cook for 6 minutes.

column1: Mchuzi wa Ndengu (Green Gram Stew),legume dishes,"Green gram stew is one of the most common legume stews in Kenya. Eaten across the country, it serves
as an accompaniment to starches such as Ugali, rice or chapatti. Sometimes green grams (or Ndengu
as they are commonly known) are used as a key ingredient in making rice dishes as well as mashed with
infant dishes.",60,30,4,"2 � cups (544 g) green gram, dry, raw
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (118 g)
column5: 7 tbsp. (84 g) cooking oil
column6: 2 � tsp. (13 g) salt, iodized","Sort and wash all the green grams.
column7: Add the raw green grams to a cooking pot and boil in 8 cups of water for 51 minutes.
column8: Drain and discard the excess water.
column9: Peel, wash and chop the onion and tomatoes.
column10: ,454,4.2,9.3,6.3,4.0,4,1.6,0.57,,<stewing>: Add oil to a cooking pot and heat for 2 minutes.
column11: Add the onions.
column13: Cook onions for 3 minutes and then add the tomatoes.
column14: Cook for another 3 minutes and then add the

column1: boiled green grams.
column2: Add 2 3/4 cups of water. Add salt and mix.
column3: Cover the vessel and cook for 14 minutes.

column1: Beef Stew,"meats, fish & eggs","Beef stew is the most common animal protein based stew in Kenya. It is prepared in different ways with
the standard ingredients featured in this recipe. It is usually eaten with starchy dishes such as Ugali, rice,
potatoes, chapatti or mashed dishes. It is more common in urban areas than in rural areas. Often, it is
served for lunch or dinner and is relished by the entire family.",10,25,4,"1 kg beef, medium fat, without bone, raw
column2: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (164 g)
column3: 3 tomatoes, red, ripe (304 g)
column5: 1� tbsp. (20 g) cooking oil
column6: 3 1/8 cups (682 g) water","Peel, wash and chop the onions and the tomatoes into separate bowls.
column7: Cut beef into small pieces and wash.
column8: Boil the meat in all the water until tender. Turn off the heat, strain the remaining water and place the meat in a separate bowl.
column9: Heat cooking oil in a cooking pot for 1 minute.
column10: Add onions and cook until soft.
column11: Add tomatoes and salt and cook until soft
column12: Add the boiled meat and stir.
column13: Add the liquid drained from boiling the meat, stir and cover to cook for 8 minutes.

column1: Stir Fried Goat Meat,"meats, fish & eggs","In most cases goat meat is stir fried rather than stewed. It is common in many communities across the
country. It is eaten with starchy dishes including rice, Ugali among others.",7,100,4,"1 kg meat, goat, medium fat, raw
column2: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (106 g)
column3: 3 tomatoes, red, ripe, chopped (336 g)
column5: 1 � tsp. (7 g) salt, iodized
column6: 2 � cups (494 g) water","Cut the goat meat into small pieces.
column7: Add the meat, all the water and salt into a cooking pot. Bring the mixture to a boil.
column8: Meanwhile, prepare and cut the onions and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column9: Add the onions and continue boiling.
column10: When all the water has dried, add oil and stir.
column11: Add tomatoes and stir.

column1: Stir Fried Beef,"meats, fish & eggs","Stir fried beef is common across many communities in Kenya even though it is more popular among urban
dwellers than rural dwellers. It is eaten with starchy foods such as Ugali, rice, potatoes or bananas. Often,
it is enjoyed by the entire family and served during lunch or dinner.",10,60,4,"1 kg beef, raw, medium fat
column3: 2 onions, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (176 g)
column5: 3 tbsp. (36 g) cooking oil
column6: 1 � tsp. (7 g) salt, iodized","Cut the beef into small pieces.
column7: Peel, wash and chop the onions and tomatoes into separate bowls.
column8: Put the meat into a cooking pot, add 3 cups of water and boil for 1 hour.
column9: Strain the remaining liquid and keep separately.
column10: Heat oil in a cooking pot, add onions and cook until golden brown.
column11: Add tomatoes and cook until tender.
column12: Add salt and meat then stir and cook for 7-10 minutes.
column13: Add half of the strained water then stir and cover to cook for 30 minutes.
column14: Add the rest of the strained water and cook until all the water dries.

column1: Ingokho  (Stewed Chicken),poultry,"Stewed chicken is common among many communities in Kenya. It has different names but ingokho stands
out due to the way this dish is special to the Luhya community. It is eaten as a protein to a main meal and
served with Ugali or any other starch. It is savoured by the entire family.",15,75,4,"1.4 kg chicken, whole
column3: � green capsicum (187 g)
column5: 4 tomatoes, red, ripe (504 g)","Light a charcoal stove. Put a mesh over the fire to singe any thin feathers and lightly brown the skin of the chicken.
column6: After 12 minutes, cut the chicken into large chunks and continue roasting for another 5 minutes or until ready. Remove from the fire.
column7: Cut the chicken into smaller portions and return the pieces onto the fire for another 11 minutes.
column8: Put the chicken onto a heated pan. Cook the chicken without added oil/ fat to brown further. Keep turning for the chicken to cook evenly.
column9: Add salt to the chicken and keep turning.
column10: Add the whole green capsicum into the pan with chicken. Turn the stove to low heat and let it simmer for 9 minutes.
column11: Prepare the onions and tomatoes. Chop into small pieces in separate bowls.
column12: Add the onions, cover and continue cooking for another 25 minutes.
column13: Remove the whole green capsicum from the pot and immediately add tomatoes.

column1: Ingokho  (Fried Chicken),poultry," Ingokho  as it is commonly known among the Luhya community is such a special delicacy. Traditionally, it
was eaten during special occasions such as dowry ceremonies. In modern practice, fried chicken is eaten
as part of a main meal served during lunch or supper. It is relished by the entire family and can be eaten
with Ugali, chapatti, or any other starch.  ",10,60,4,"1.3 kg whole chicken
column3: 3 1/8 cups (623 g) cooking oil",Cut the chicken into large chunks.
column5: Place a pan on fire and add oil.
column6: Add salt to the chicken and rub in.
column7: Heat oil for 6 minutes.
column8: Gently place the chicken pieces into the pan and turn every 3 minutes until the skin is golden brown.

column1: Aluru (Stewed Quails),poultry,"Stewed quails commonly known as  Aluru  is a traditional dish typical to the Luhya and Luo communities.
Aluru was prepared during special occasions. It is commonly known as Likhanga among the Luhya community.  ",12,60,4,"3 quails, whole (507 g)
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (76 g)
column5: 2 cups (517 g) cow s milk
column6: 3 � cups (679 g) cooking oil",Roast the quails for 10 minutes and remove the innards.
column7: Add 3 cups of cooking oil onto a clean dry pot and heat.Put in the quails and fry for 11 minutes.Remove and use paper towels to drain the oil.Wash and chop the onion and tomatoes and place into separate bowls.Add � a cup of cooking oil into a separate cooking pot and the chopped onions.Cook until golden brown then add the tomatoes.Cook it for 3 minutes or until the tomatoes are tender.Add salt and stir. Cook for 5 minutes.Add milk followed by the fried quails.Cover and cook for 12 minutes.Remove from heat and serve.,809,14.2,5.2,11.3,0.6,51,1.6,1.24,,

column1: Sukuma Wiki (Stir-fried Kales),vegetable dishes,"Sukuma wiki is the most commonly used green vegetable in Kenya. It is commonly served with Ugali as a
side dish.",15,20,4,"sukuma wiki leaves raw (2667 g)
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (184 g)
column5: � tsp. (3 g) salt, iodized","Wash the sukuma wiki and then remove the stalks.
column6: Roll up a handful of sukuma wiki leaves into a bunch and chop them finely.
column7: Wash, prepare and cut the onion and tomatoes separately.
column8: Place a cooking pot on the fire. Add cooking oil.
column9: Cook the onion until golden brown.
column10: Add tomatoes into the pot.
column11: Cook tomatoes until ready.
column12: Add the chopped sukuma wiki and salt.
column14: Simmer over low heat for 5 minutes.

column1: Stir-fried Cabbage,vegetable dishes,Stir fried cabbage is common in many communities in Kenya. It is served with various starchy dishes as a side dish.,10,15,4,"1124 g cabbage, white, raw
column3: � cup (83 g) cooking oil
column4: 2 � tsp. (12 g) salt, iodized",Prepare and cut the onions and the cabbage into separate bowls.
column5: Add the cooking oil into a cooking pot over fire and then put the chopped onions. Stir the onion and cook for 2 minutes.
column6: Add the cabbage and stir.
column7: Add salt and continue to stir the cabbage to cook it evenly.
column8: Cook for an additional 5 minutes.

column1: Mrenda and Seveve  (Jute Mallow & Pumpkin Leaves),vegetable dishes,"This blend of  mrenda  and pumpkin leaves is a traditional vegetable dish among the Luhya community.
It is usually served with Ugali.",15,30,4,"316 g jute mallow leaves, raw
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (75 g)
column5: 2/3 cup (134 g) water
column6: 1 tomato, red, ripe (145 g)
column7: 1 � cups (410 g) cow s milk","Wash and pluck the leaves from the stalks of the jute mallow.
column8: Wash and chop the pumpkin leaves.
column9: Prepare, wash and cut the onion and tomato into separate bowls.
column10: Boil all the water and put the leafy vegetables into the boiling water and cook on low heat for 5 minutes.
column11: Stir the vegetables
column13: Cook for 5 minutes and then add all the milk.
column14: Stir and cook for another 5 minutes.

column1: Stewed Potatoes & Arrowroots,root & banana dishes,"Stewed arrowroots is a nostalgic dish traditional to the arrowroot growing regions. The Kikuyu, Meru and
Embu communities are key to this recipe. It is eaten as a main meal during lunch or supper and is relished
by the entire family.",15,60,4,"9 potatoes, unpeeled, Irish, white (1 kg)
column3: 6 green bananas, unpeeled, raw (1.2 kg)
column4: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (185 g)
column5: 3 tomatoes, red, ripe (511 g)
column6: 1/3 cup (69 g) cooking oil
column7: 3 tsp. (15 g) salt, iodized
column8: 7 cups (1534 g) water","Peel and wash the potatoes, arrowroots, onions and tomatoes.
column9: Cut the washed ingredients into cubes in separate bowls.
column10: Peel and wash the bananas and keep them in a separate bowl with water (this water is not for cooking but to prevent bananas from browning).
column11: Heat the cooking oil in a cooking vessel for 2 minutes and add onions, cook for 12 minutes until golden brown.
column12: Add tomatoes and cook for 8 minutes.
column14: Add the chopped potatoes and stir.
column15: Add 4 cups of water and cook for another 4 minutes.
column16: Add cut arrowroots and cover to cook for 17 minutes.
column17: Add the bananas and 3 cups of water then stir and let to it cook for 13 minutes. Serve.",380,2.1,15.0,1.9,1.8,3,0.9,0.44,,

column1: Yam Stew,root & banana dishes,"The ancient yam is among the oldest roots in Kenya. It is a traditional delicacy of the Meru community.
To date, yams are eaten as a stew as indicated in this recipe. It can also be prepared with meat or other
protein. Loved for its filling effect, yam stew is packed with good wholesome starch ideal for the health
conscious. It can be eaten during lunch or dinner as a main dish served to the whole family.",20,60,4,"1 yam, white, raw (2 kg)
column3: 1 onion, red skinned, raw, unpeeled (175 g)
column5: 2 carrots, orange, raw (245 g)
column6: 1 � tbsp. (22 g) salt, iodized
column7: 1/3 cup (76 g) cooking oil
column8: 4 3/4 cups (1036 g) water","Peel, wash and cut the yam into small pieces.
column9: Peel and wash the potatoes in water.
column10: Cut the potatoes into small cubes.
column11: Peel, wash and cut the tomatoes, carrots and the onions.
column12: Heat the oil for 1 minute then add the onions.
column14: Add salt after 5 minutes. After 6 minutes add the cut yam and stir.
column15: After 8 minutes add all the water and cover the pot.
column16: After 6 minutes add potatoes, stir and cover.
column18: Heat for 20 minutes and remove from the fire.

column1: Pumpkins with Peanut Butter,root & banana dishes,"This sweet, buttery recipe is an infant dish served typically for lunch or dinner by the urban communities.",5,45,4,"1.5 kg pumpkin raw unpeeled
column3: 7 tbsp. (109 g) peanut butter
column5: 2 1/8 cups (466 g) water
column6: 1 � tsp. (7 g) salt, iodized","Peel and wash the pumpkin.
column7: In a separate bowl mix the peanut butter with 1/8 cup of water.
column8: Put the pumpkin into a cooking pot and add the rest of the water.
column9: Bring to boil, add salt and cooking oil.
column10: When the pumpkin has cooked, add the peanut paste.
column11: Cover and simmer for 9 minutes.

column1: White Chapati,accompaniments,"This dish is common in many communities in Kenya and even more popular in the urban communities.
The white chapatti is made from refined wheat flour and is eaten with a meat, legume or vegetable stew.
Chapatti is often made during special occasions. It is served as an accompaniment during lunch or dinner
and at times eaten with tea for breakfast.  ",30,30,6,"4 1/3 cups (576 g) wheat flour, refined, fortified
column3: 1 tsp. (5 g) white sugar
column5: ¾ cup (168 g) cooking oil","Measure flour, salt, sugar, cooking oil and water into separate bowls.
column6: Mix the dry ingredients
column7: flour, sugar and salt.
column8: Warm all the water and add into the dry ingredients mixture.
column9: Knead the mixture to soft dough for 6 minutes.
column10: Set the dough aside and cover for 16 minutes before use.
column11: Place the cast iron pan over the fire and heat.
column12: Dust the working surface lightly with flour and start rolling the dough to desired thickness.
column13: Apply ¼ cup oil on top, cut into strips and roll strips into balls of desired size.
column14: Cover with cling film or a clean kitchen towel and let the dough rest.
column15: Cooking oil is added into the mixture either in water, in dry ingredients or when kneading. You can also use oil to cover the dough to prevent it from drying/ crusting. Oil can also be applied on top.
column16: Start rolling each ball on a lightly floured work surface into a disc shape.
column17: Cook each chapati on the pan one at a time until lightly browned on both sides.
column18: Lightly oil each side and turn before removing it from the heat. Repeat for all the chapati’s.
column19: Stack up the cooked chapati as you remove them from the pan. Keep covered.",1774,21.1,49.6,7.8,2.5,59,3.9,0.61,,

column1: Brown Chapati,accompaniments,"Brown chapatti is another variant of chapatti and is common among many communities in Kenya. It is
preferred for the health-conscious people due to the high fibre content as it is made of whole wheat flour.
It is served as an accompaniment during lunch, dinner or breakfast.",30,30,7,"3 2/3 cups (414 g) wheat flour, whole, atta
column3: 1 tsp. (5 g) sugar, white
column5: 2/3 cup (134 g) cooking oil","Measure flour, salt, sugar, cooking oil and water into separate bowls.
column6: Heat all water for 4 minutes. The water should be warm not boiling.
column7: Mix the ingredients
column8: flour, sugar and salt into a mixing bowl.
column9: Pour all the warm water into the dry mixture.
column10: Knead the mixture to soft dough.
column11: Set the dough into a bowl and cover for 15 minutes before use.
column12: Put the pan over fire and heat.
column13: Dust the working surface with flour and start rolling the dough to desired thickness.
column14: Cut the rolled into strips and roll the strips into round balls.
column15: Cover with cling film, damp cloth or any suitable material to prevent the dough from drying and/ or forming a crust.
column16: Roll out the balls one at a time into a disc shape.
column17: Cook each the chapati on the pan, turning to cook on both sides. Lightly, oil each side and fry until browned.
column18: Each chapati cooks for 3 minutes until golden brown.
column19: Remove from fire and stack them up. Keep covered.",1723,22.9,40.9,7.3,7.2,1,2.4,1.5,,

column1: Roti (Indian Chapati),accompaniments,"Roti is the Indian version of chapatti. It is common among the Kenyan Indian community. Usually, Roti is
part of an assortment of dishes that make up a platter for a main meal. It is eaten as an accompaniment.",180,21,4,"1 3/4 cups (227 g) wheat flour, whole
column3: 3/4 cup (163 g) water
column5: 2 ½ tbsp. (34 g) cow ghee","Put wheat flour into a bowl, add salt and ghee.
column6: Add ¾ cup of water while kneading.
column7: Knead the mixture into soft dough.
column8: Cover and leave to rest for 3 hours.
column9: Heat a pan for 2 minutes. Put a drop of cooking oil.
column10: Roll the dough into circular discs of desired sizes and place them on the pan.
column11: Fry for 3 minutes until they turn brown or while turning continuously.
column12: Add a little oil if necessary.
column13: Remove and repeat the process for all the pieces.",1560,16.7,43.8,8,7.9,44,2.7,1.64,,

column1: Whole Maize Flour Ugali,ugali,"This recipe represents the most consumed Ugali in all communities in Kenya. It is eaten as a main dish
during lunch or supper usually accompanied by a vegetable or protein dish.",5,25,4,"3 2/3 cups (495 g) whole maize flour, white
column2: 4 3/4 cups (1026 g) water","Measure water and flour into separate bowls.
column3: Put all the water into a cooking pot, cover and bring to a boil.
column4: Add flour into the boiling water and keep mixing while pressing against the wall of the cooking pot until the mixture is smooth without lumps.
column5: Once properly mixed, reduce the fire and simmer for 13 minutes.

column1: Maize and Finger Millet Flour Ugali,ugali,"This variant of Ugali is prepared from a combination of finger millet and whole maize flour. It is common
among the Kisii, Luhya, Kamba, Kalenjin and Luo communities. It is served as a main dish accompanied by
a vegetable or meat dish.",5,30,4,"2 cups (253 g) whole maize flour, white
column3: 5 cups (1149 g) water","Mix the dry ingredients together
column4: whole maize meal and finger millet flour, until an even colour is obtained.
column5: Boil all the water in a cooking pot.
column6: Pour ¾ of the mixed flour into the cooking pot and slowly start mixing.
column7: Continue mixing for 2 minutes.
column8: Add the remaining quarter of the flour while mixing. Mix while pressing the mixture against the wall of the pot to avoid forming lumps. Continue mixing until smooth.
column9: Reduce the fire after 2 minutes of cooking and simmer for 17 minutes until ready.
column10: While simmering, keep mixing periodically.
column11: Remove from fire, turn over onto a plate and serve hot.",562,1.3,24,3.1,6.6,0,2.9,0.73,,

column1: Maize, Red Sorghum and Finger Millet flour Ugali,ugali,"This variant of Ugali is common as a traditional dish among the Kalenjin, the Luhya and Luo communities.
It is served as a main dish often accompanied by a vegetable dish or a meat/fish dish.",5,25,4,"2 cups (255 g) whole maize flour, white
column3: 1 cup finger millet (113 g) flour
column4: 5 cups (1139 g) water","Put all the water into a cooking pot and bring to a boil.
column5: Meanwhile, mix the dry ingredients
column6: whole maize flour, finger millet, red sorghum until an even colour is attained.
column7: Pour the dry mixture all at once into the cooking pot and slowly start mixing everything.
column8: Mix while pressing the mixture against the walls of the pot to avoid forming lumps.
column9: Continue mixing the paste until smooth.
column10: Reduce the fire and simmer for 8 minutes.
column11: Remove from fire, turn over onto a plate and serve hot.",543,1.4,23.3,3.1,5.3,0,1.9,0.72,,

column1: Vimumunya vya Sukari (Sweetened Pumpkin & Coconut Milk),desserts and sauces,This is a famous Swahili dessert that is served after meals. It is eaten by the entire family.,5,45,4,"pumpkin, unpeeled (1.7 kg)
column3: ½ cup (113 g) sugar
column5: 3 3/4 cups (810 g) water","Peel pumpkin and cut into large chunks.
column6: Put the pumpkin onto a cooking pot, add all the water and put on heat.
column7: Bring to a boil for 17 minutes.
column8: Add half the amount of coconut milk and boil for 6 minutes.
column9: Add sugar and cardamoms.
column10: Add the rest of the coconut milk. Cover and cook for 18 more minutes.
